message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on prostate cancer screening for help. The most appropriate recommendation for prostate cancer screening in a man with a family history of prostate cancer is serum PSA level. TRUS and contrast CT are not first-line screening tests for prostate cancer. No screening is only appropriate for men with limited life expectancy or who have decided against screening.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's age and family history put him at risk for prostate cancer, and while there is no consensus on the best screening approach, measuring serum PSA level is commonly recommended. TRUS and CT scan are not typically used for routine screening. Therefore, the most appropriate recommendation for prostate cancer screening in this patient is (B) serum PSA level.

We refer to guidelines on prostate cancer screening from reputable sources such as the American Cancer Society. As the patient has an uncle who died of prostate cancer and is at average risk for prostate cancer, a serum PSA level is the most appropriate screening test to perform. Transrectal ultrasound and CT scan are not recommended for routine screening. No screening is only for men with limited life expectancy or who do not wish to be screened.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s uncle's prostate cancer history and age put him at an increased risk for prostate cancer. The most appropriate screening for prostate cancer in this patient is a serum prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level. TRUS and CT imaging are not recommended for routine prostate cancer screening. No screening is also not appropriate given the patient’s risk factors.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Since the patient has a family history of prostate cancer and is over the age of 50, he should undergo screening for prostate cancer. The most appropriate initial screening test is a serum PSA level. TRUS and CT scan are not recommended as initial screening tests. No screening is also not indicated given the patient's risk factors.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's age, family history, and being male are risk factors for prostate cancer. The most appropriate next step is to recommend a serum PSA level test for prostate cancer screening. There is no indication for TRUS or contrast CT at this time, and no screening is not recommended given the patient's risk factors.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. This patient has no significant findings on physical examination but does have a family history of prostate cancer. The most appropriate recommendation for prostate cancer screening in this patient would be a serum PSA level. TRUS and CT scans are not typically recommended as routine screening modalities for prostate cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s family history of prostate cancer and age suggest that he should have prostate cancer screening. PSA level testing is recommended for men aged 55 to 69. TRUS and CT scans are not recommended for routine screening for prostate cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s age, family history, and being male put him at average risk for prostate cancer. Therefore, the most appropriate recommendation for prostate cancer screening in this patient is a serum PSA level. TRUS and contrast CT of the abdomen and pelvis are generally not recommended for routine prostate cancer screening.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s past medical history and family history put him at an increased risk for prostate cancer, and he is within the age range for screening. The most appropriate recommendation for screening is a serum PSA level. TRUS and CT scans are not recommended as routine screening tests for prostate cancer. No screening is only recommended for patients with a life expectancy of less than 10 years.
